body.p: This document describes the configuration process and requirements for the HP Helion OpenStack 2.0 Firewall as a Service module.

section.title: Prerequisites
section.p: HP Helion OpenStack must be installed.

section.title: Configuration
section.p: You can create a set of Firewall rules, add them to a policy and associate it with a Firewall by executing the following commands from a shell with access to the API nodes.

ol.li: Display the available neutron extensions.neutron ext-list
Display the available networks.neutron net-list
Display the available machines and networks. nova list

section.p: You can set up networks for FWaaS by creating a network, subnet, router, security group rules, security group filters and floating IP's.

ol.li: Create the network, subnet and router. neutron net-create net1 neutron subnet-create --name sub1 net1 10.0.0.0/24 --gateway 10.0.0.1 neutron router-create router1 neutron router-interface-add router1 sub1 neutron router-gateway-set router1 ext-net

Create security group rules. Security group rules filters traffic at VM level. nova secgroup-add-rule default tcp 22 22 0.0.0.0/0 nova secgroup-add-rule default tcp 80 80 0.0.0.0/0 nova secgroup-add-rule default icmp -1 -1 0.0.0.0/0
Boot a VM. NET=$(neutron net-list | awk '/net1/ {print $2}') nova boot --flavor 1 --image cirros-0.3.3-x86_64 --nic net-id=$NET vm1 --poll
Verify if the instance is ACTIVE and is assigned an IP address. nova list
Create a floating IP in the ext-net. neutron floatingip-create ext-net fluuid=$(neutron floatingip-list | awk '/172.16/ {print $2}') echo "Floating IP UUID = $fluuid" neutron floatingip-list
Get the fixed IP of the VM instance. fixedip=$(nova list | awk '/Running/ {print $12}' | awk -F '=' '{print $2}') echo "VM fixed IP = $fixedip"

Associate the floating ip with the VM instacne. vmportuuid=$(neutron port-list | grep $fixedip | awk '{print $2}') echo "Port ID for VM port is $vmportuuid" neutron floatingip-associate $fluuid $vmportuuid neutron floatingip-list fip=$(neutron floatingip-list | awk '/172.16/ {print $6}') echo "Floating IP = $fip"

Verify that you are able to ssh into the instance from the host machine. To make the external net accessible, HOSTIP is the IP of nearest machine. ssh ubuntu@$HOSTIP 'sudo ip addr add 172.16.0.1/16 dev virbr4'
Attempt to log into the VM instance. ssh ubuntu@$HOSTIP ssh-keygen -R $fip ssh -t ubuntu@$HOSTIP ssh cirros@$fip
Ping the router gateway. ping 10.0.0.1 ping 172.16.0.2

section.note: By default, an internal "drop all" rule is enabled in IP tables if none of the defines rules match the real-time data packets.

ol.li: Create new firewall rules using firewall-rule-create and providing the protocol, action (allow, deny) and name for the new rule. This example allows icmp and ssh while denying access to http. See the neutron command-line reference under more information on additional options such as source IP, destination IP, source port and destination port.neutron firewall-rule-create --protocol icmp --action allow --name allow-icmp neutron firewall-rule-create --protocol tcp --destination-port 80 --action deny --name deny-http neutron firewall-rule-create --protocol tcp --destination-port 22 --action allow --name allow-ssh

Once the rules are created, create the firewall policy by using the firewall-policy-create command with the --firewall-rules option and rules to include in quotes, followed by the name of the new policy. The order of the rules is important. neutron firewall-policy-create --firewall-rules "allow-icmp deny-http allow-ssh" policy-fw
Finish the firewall creation by using the firewall-create command, the policy name and the new name you want to give to your new firewall. neutron firewall-create policy-fw --name user-fw
You can view the details of your new firewall by using the firewall-show command and the name of your firewall. neutron firewall-show user-fw

section.p: You should verify the FWaaS is functional with the steps included below.

ol.li: From an external network, you should be able to successfully ping the floating IP address of the instance. ping $fip
Verify from the external network that you are able to connect via ssh to the instance. ssh -t ubuntu@$HOSTIP ssh cirros@$fip
You should expect to see curl fail over port 80. If curl succeeds, the firewall is not blocking incoming http requests. The instance should be listening on port 80 to verify this test.curl -vvv $fip
